user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13 is: A pointer should point to a const-qualified type whenever possible.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of digest_reset:
```c
_MHD_static_inline void
digest_reset (struct DigestAlgorithm *da)
{
  mhd_assert (! da->uninitialised);
  mhd_assert (da->algo_selected);
  mhd_assert (! da->hashing);
#ifdef MHD_MD5_SUPPORT
  if (MHD_DIGEST_BASE_ALGO_MD5 == da->algo)
  {
#ifdef MHD_MD5_HAS_FINISH
    mhd_assert (! da->ready_for_hashing);
#else  /* ! MHD_MD5_HAS_FINISH */
    mhd_assert (da->ready_for_hashing);
#endif /* ! MHD_MD5_HAS_FINISH */
    MHD_MD5_reset (&da->ctx.md5_ctx);
#ifdef _DEBUG
    da->ready_for_hashing = true;
#endif /* _DEBUG */
  }
  else
#endif /* MHD_MD5_SUPPORT */
#ifdef MHD_SHA256_SUPPORT
  if (MHD_DIGEST_BASE_ALGO_SHA256 == da->algo)
  {
#ifdef MHD_SHA256_HAS_FINISH
    mhd_assert (! da->ready_for_hashing);
#else  /* ! MHD_SHA256_HAS_FINISH */
    mhd_assert (da->ready_for_hashing);
#endif /* ! MHD_SHA256_HAS_FINISH */
    MHD_SHA256_reset (&da->ctx.sha256_ctx);
#ifdef _DEBUG
    da->ready_for_hashing = true;
#endif /* _DEBUG */
  }
  else
#endif /* MHD_SHA256_SUPPORT */
#ifdef MHD_SHA512_256_SUPPORT
  if (MHD_DIGEST_BASE_ALGO_SHA512_256 == da->algo)
  {
    mhd_assert (! da->ready_for_hashing);
    MHD_SHA512_256_init (&da->ctx.sha512_256_ctx);
#ifdef _DEBUG
    da->ready_for_hashing = true;
#endif
  }
  else
#endif /* MHD_SHA512_256_SUPPORT */
  {
#ifdef _DEBUG
    da->ready_for_hashing = false;
#endif
    mhd_assert (0); /* May not happen, bad algorithm */
  }
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
I found no code fragments that need investigation for MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13. Reasons: 

- The function parameter is `struct DigestAlgorithm *da`. This function intentionally mutates the DigestAlgorithm instance (calls to reset/init functions and assignments like `da->ready_for_hashing = true` in debug builds), so the pointer must be non-const and cannot be changed to `const`.

- The address-of usages (e.g. `&da->ctx.md5_ctx`, `&da->ctx.sha256_ctx`, `&da->ctx.sha512_256_ctx`) are passed to reset/init functions which by their purpose modify those context structures. Those targets therefore must be non-const; making them const would be incorrect.

- The various `mhd_assert` and algorithm-selection checks only read fields, but they are part of a function that also writes state; the overall parameter cannot be const while parts are written.

- There are no other pointer declarations or pointer-typed variables in this fragment that could be const-qualified without changing semantics.

Given the above, there are no pointer uses in this code fragment that violate or are likely to violate Rule 8.13 — all non-const pointers are used to modify state and thus should remain non-const.
